questions.question: "He had the eye of a vulture," is what kind of figurative language?
"I heard all things in heaven and the earth. I heard many things in hell," is what?
"The disease had sharpened my senses," is what type of figurative language?
How do we know that something is personification?

choices.answer: Something that is not a person is described like a person.
The line is spoken by a person.

questions.question: "He had the eye of a vulture," tells the reader what fact?

choices.answer: The old man really was probably evil.
The narrator's eyes are probably not blue.
The old man is thin like a bird.
The narrator is creeped out and upset by the eye.

questions.question: How do we know that something is allusion?

choices.answer: It brings something in fiction or the real world to mind.
It is easy for a reader to picture.
It is a type of figurative speech using "like" or "as."

questions.question: "Death, in approaching him, had stalked with his black shadow before him," is which of these?
The narrator hears something which makes "a sound as a watch covered in cotton." This is...
How do we know something is a simile?

choices.answer: Something is described in a way that appeals to the senses.
Two different things are compared using "like" or "as."
Something real or from another fictional work is alluded to.
Something which is not a person is given human qualities.

questions.question: "A single dim ray, like the thread of a spider," is what kind of figurative language?
A type of figurative language makes the reader think about a thing without directly naming it?
"I heard many things in hell," is an example of what type of figurative language?
"I heard all things in heaven and the earth. I heard many things in hell," is what?
Why is death personified in, "Death, in approaching him, had stalked with his black shadow?"

choices.answer: The narrator believes that death really is a person.
The narrator thinks that the old man can't die.
The narrator thought this would make a cool album cover.
The narrator is sees himself as death stalking the old man.

questions.question: Why does the narrator decide to kill the old man?

choices.answer: Money, because the old man is rich.
They fought about politics all the time.
The old man was mean and selfish.
The narrator is afraid of the old man's eye.

questions.question: "His room was black as pitch in the covered darkness," is an example of...
Why does Poe describe the old man as a corpse after his death?

choices.answer: To give the reader an appealing image.
To show how rational the narrator is.
To give the reader a sense of how lifeless the body is.

questions.question: While talking to the police, the narrator says, "I fancied I heard a ringing in my ears." Why?

choices.answer: The narrator hears church bells far away.
The narrator hears a sound that everyone else is ignoring.
The narrator begins to suffer from a bad headache.
The narrator begins to imagine he hears a ringing sound.

questions.question: How do we know that something is a symbol?

choices.answer: It is often something simple that stands for a larger idea.
It is a figure of speech using "like" or "as."
It is descriptive language that appeals to the senses.
It compares two unlike things as though they were the same.

questions.question: "A single dim ray, like the thread of a spider," is what kind of figurative language?
